docs.lead_paragraph: Consumer confidence fell this month as concerns about unemployment and the reliability of company earnings reports dimmed enthusiasm that had been building since September, a private research group said today. The Conference Board reported that its gauge of sentiment dropped to 94.1 after rising to 97.8 in January. The decline was the first in three months and was larger than expected. More than 80 percent of those surveyed indicated they were concerned about jobs.

docs.lead_paragraph: AT a run-through for ''Into the Woods'' in a New York rehearsal studio, just before the new version of the 1987 Stephen Sondheim musical came here, Vanessa Williams, the star, was startled to find the audience of families and friends weeping. It was the second act of the fairy-tale fantasy, when several characters die brutally at the hands of an evil giant and cast members begin singing the plaintive ballad about shared sacrifice, ''No One Is Alone.'' Sometimes people leave you Halfway through the wood. Do not let it grieve you, No one leaves for good. You are not alone. No one is alone.

docs.snippet: MOVIES have given audiences countless previews of death, but they rarely force us to grieve. In film, death is usually an action sequence. Grief is reduced to a pantomime of denials and screams, of tears and silences. But a number of recent films ...
docs.lead_paragraph: MOVIES have given audiences countless previews of death, but they rarely force us to grieve. In film, death is usually an action sequence. Grief is reduced to a pantomime of denials and screams, of tears and silences. But a number of recent films -- several of them nominated for Academy Awards -- have taken a long look at the mourning that usually passes off-screen. And it might be a sign of the times that audiences have seemed drawn to movies about the loss of life. Grief is often portrayed in melodramatic scenes. The deserted go looking for the dead in empty rooms, searching their pockets, breathing in their unwashed clothes. But grief can cause even stranger behavior. In Todd Louiso's forthcoming ''Love Liza,'' Philip Seymour Hoffman plays a husband who can't bring himself to read the suicide note left by his wife; instead he devotes himself to sniffing gasoline. In Wes Anderson's ''Royal Tenenbaums,'' which was nominated for best original screenplay, Chas Tenenbaum (Ben Stiller) turns his grief over his wife's accidental death into a campaign against avoidable disaster. He is an amateur fire marshal and safety officer who tries to transform his powerlessness into endless plans of action. Chas doesn't stop to put his arms around his sons, and the movie doesn't let us really stop to contemplate his grief; it keeps us laughing with the absurd running joke of his voodoo dance against the inevitable. But the emotion beneath the odd comedy of his manner begins to creep up on you after a while.
docs.abstract: Kristin Hohenadel article on number of recent films, several nominated for Academy Awards, that focus on mourning and grief, including Todd Louiso's forthcoming Love Liza, Todd Field's In the Bedroom and Marc Forster's Monster's Ball; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN a rehearsal room eight floors above West 43rd Street, a wiry wisp of a gent is standing so close to the actors that you might mistake him for their dermatologist. When they speak their lines, it is he who registers the biggest reactions: looks of surprise, admiration, worry cross his face in a cascade of emotion. The actors, Alan Bates and Enid Graham, are working out the subtle physical gestures in a central scene of ''Fortune's Fool,'' an adaptation of ''A Poor Gentleman,'' a little-known 1848 play by Ivan Turgenev.

docs.lead_paragraph: She was born in Bermuda. Her mother wrote short stories; her father, a chronic alcoholic, was the only American playwright to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature. Barely a toddler when her father ran off with another woman, she and her older brother were raised by their mother. Her formal education ended at Brearley, an exclusive girls' school in New York City. Accepted by Vassar College, she chose instead to seek an acting career, and following a fleeting appearance in summer stock, went to Hollywood and met her future husband. He was 36 years her senior, thrice divorced and a comic genius. When she turned 18, they married. Immediately, her father disowned and disinherited her. The marriage, however, endured; she had eight children, and remained with her husband for 34 years until his death in 1977. Her mother was Agnes Boulton, her father was Eugene O'Neill, and her husband was Charlie Chaplin. She was beautiful, charming, intelligent and appealing, and more than a half century ago, Oona O'Neill Chaplin was America's darling.
docs.abstract: Life of Oona O'Neill Chaplin is recalled by Jane Scoville, her biographer; photo of Charles and Oona Chaplin and one fashion photo inspired by it with Kate Beckinsale as Oona (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN she is not deflecting bullets or tearing a swath through Manhattan, a steel gauntlet and dagger fused to her wrist, Sara Pezzini, the supernaturally gifted detective of ''Witchblade,'' is busy gleaning wisdom. On the cable show's pilot episode, rebroadcast last week, Sara is all ears, as a ghostly companion urges her to ''open the doors of perception'' and to realize that ''there is a lot more going on around you than you know.'' Right. An eerie parallel universe teeming with monks, gargoyles, gnomes and knights has indeed seeped into Sara's dreams and encroached on her waking life as well. It is a storybook world straight out of Camelot, and a realm not far removed from the one currently invading the popular psyche by way of fiction, film -- and, lately, fashion too.

docs.snippet: I was sitting in the restaurant Tong Yen off the Champs-Élysées in Paris, when Robert Altman came in with a large party of ''show people,'' including Lauren Bacall and Stephen Rea. ''Prêt-à-Porter'' was in preproduction (it was 1994), and I be...
docs.lead_paragraph: I was sitting in the restaurant Tong Yen off the Champs-Élysées in Paris, when Robert Altman came in with a large party of ''show people,'' including Lauren Bacall and Stephen Rea. ''Prêt-à-Porter'' was in preproduction (it was 1994), and I believe I was the only one of the ''fashion people'' at my table who didn't make haste to meet the storied auteur. I paid my homage at a safe distance, in a wallflower way: by entertaining the troops with dialogue from ''Three Women,'' Altman's hypnotic and hilarious 1977 film about personality theft, starring Shelley Duvall and Sissy Spacek. (Waiter: ''Du vin?'' Me: ''Y'all got Tickled Pink -- or Lemon Satin?'' Waiter: ''Non.'') It is one of my favorite movies ever.
docs.abstract: Brian D Leitch article on Robert Altman's 1973 film The Long Goodbye, heretical take on Raymond Chandler; photo (M)
